docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision 3 Experts’ reports and expert evidence [rr 31.27–31.36]

heading.title: DIVISION 2 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EXPERT EVIDENCE GENERALLY [rr 31.17–31.54]
Subdivision 3 Experts’ reports and expert evidence [rr 31.27–31.36]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 2 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EXPERT EVIDENCE GENERALLY [rr 31.17–31.54]
Subdivision 3 Experts’ reports and expert evidence [rr 31.27–31.36]
[r 31.27] r 31.27 Experts’ reports (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13C; DCR Part 28, rule 9C; LCR Part 23, rule 1D)

leg:heading.title: Experts’ reports (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13C; DCR Part 28, rule 9C; LCR Part 23, rule 1D)

p.text: An expert’s report must (in the body of the report or in an annexure to it) include the following:
the expert’s qualifications as an expert on the issue the subject of the report,
the facts, and assumptions of fact, on which the opinions in the report are based (a letter of instructions may be annexed),
the expert’s reasons for each opinion expressed,
if applicable, that a particular issue falls outside the expert’s field of expertise,
any literature or other materials utilised in support of the opinions,
any examinations, tests or other investigations on which the expert has relied, including details of the qualifications of the person who carried them out,
in the case of a report that is lengthy or complex, a brief summary of the report (to be located at the beginning of the report).
If an expert witness who prepares an expert’s report believes that it may be incomplete or inaccurate without some qualification, the qualification must be stated in the report.

If an expert witness considers that his or her opinion is not a concluded opinion because of insufficient research or insufficient data or for any other reason, this must be stated when the opinion is expressed.

If an expert witness changes his or her opinion on a material matter after providing an expert’s report to the party engaging him or her (or that party’s legal representative), the expert witness must forthwith provide the engaging party (or that party’s legal representative) with a supplementary report to that effect containing such of the information referred to in subrule (1) as is appropriate.

level.toc-caption: [31.27.5] Form of expert’s report

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.27.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Schedule 7, r 31.23, r 31.27.

An expert report must comply with the Schedule 7 Code of Conduct: UCPR r 31.23 . The requirements of the code, relating to the form of the expert report, are substantially reproduced in UCPR r 31.27 . These provisions are not intended to operate directly as rules of admissibility. Their primary intention is to operate as a code of conduct designed to improve the quality of expert evidence: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2005) 190 FLR 242; 53 ACSR 110; [2005] NSWSC 149; BC200501057 at [333] . As to the consequences of non-compliance with the code and the rules see [31.23.10] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.28] r 31.28 Disclosure of experts’ reports and hospital reports (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13A; DCR Part 28, rule 8; LCR Part 23, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Disclosure of experts’ reports and hospital reports (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13A; DCR Part 28, rule 8; LCR Part 23, rule 3)

p.text: Each party must serve experts’ reports and hospital reports on each other active party:
in accordance with any order of the court, or
if no such order is in force, in accordance with any relevant practice note, or
if no such order or practice note is in force, not later than 28 days before the date of the hearing at which the report is to be used.
An application to the court for an order under subrule (1) (other than an order solely for abridgment or extension of time) may be made without serving notice of motion.
Except by leave of the court, or by consent of the parties:
an expert’s report or hospital report is not admissible unless it has been served in accordance with this rule, and

without limiting paragraph (a), an expert’s report or hospital report, when tendered under section 63 , 64 or 69 of the Evidence Act 1995, is not admissible unless it has been served in accordance with this rule, and

the oral expert evidence in chief of any expert is not admissible unless an expert’s report or hospital report served in accordance with this rule contains the substance of the matters sought to be adduced in evidence.
Leave is not to be given as referred to in subrule (3) unless the court is satisfied:
that there are exceptional circumstances that warrant the granting of leave, or
that the report concerned merely updates an earlier version of a report that has been served in accordance with subrule (1).

level.toc-caption: [31.28.2] Relevant practice note

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 31.28.
For the purposes of UCPR r 31.28 , see Practice Note DC (Civil) No 1 at [8.6], reproduced in vol 2 at [DC (Civil) 1] .

level.toc-caption: [31.28.5] Ambit of rule — opinion evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 31.18.

The disclosure obligation imposed by this rule applies only to an “expert report” — ie, a written statement setting out a relevant opinion: see the definition in UCPR r 31.18 . It does not apply to evidence given by an "expert" relating to purely factual matters: South Western Sydney Area Health Service v Ritchie (NSWCA, Priestley, Meagher and Stein JJA, No 40611/96, 13 November 1998, unreported, BC9806058).

level.toc-caption: [31.28.10] Admissibility dependent on disclosure or leave

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 31.34.

heading.title: Admissibility dependent on disclosure or leave

p.text: The effect of this rule (and UCPR r 31.34 ) is to require prior service of those reports each party intends to tender as evidence in the proceedings: Alucraft Pty Ltd (in liq) v Grocon Ltd (No 1) [1996] 2 VR 377; BC9300981 (leave refused). (The disclosure requirement does not extend to other reports the parties might have obtained.) The duty to disclose also applies to supplementary reports. If an expert furnishes the engaging party with a supplementary report that affects an earlier report, including a supplementary report indicating that the expert has changed his opinion on a material, the engaging party must serve the supplementary report on all parties on whom the earlier report was served. Failure to serve the supplementary report will bar the use of the earlier report in the proceedings: see UCPR r 31.34 .

level.toc-caption: [31.28.12] “Back-serving” of reports

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 31.28(1).

A practice of “back-serving” expert’s reports has developed in the District Court. If party A has served an expert’s report on party B, and party B wishes to keep the option of itself tendering the report at the hearing, party B then serves a copy of the report on party A, notwithstanding that it was party A who commissioned the preparation of the report. This is presumably a response to uncertainty about the meaning of UCPR r 31.28(1) . For discussion of this practice and the construction of UCPR r 31.28(1) see Yacoub v Pilkington [2007] NSWCA 290; BC200709104 at [63] ff per Campbell JA.

level.toc-caption: [31.28.15] Extension of time for service of expert reports

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12, r 2.1, r 31.28(1), r 31.28(3), r 31.28(4).

heading.title: Extension of time for service of expert reports

p.text: The conditional prohibition contained in r 31.28(3) applies unless the reports have been served “in accordance with this rule”. Rule 31.28(1) alternatively requires service within 28 days of the hearing, in compliance with a relevant Practice Note or service in accordance with “any order of the court”. This rule must be read with the general directions power conferred by r 2.1 (to give directions “at any time and from time to time”) as well as the power conferred by r 1.12 (to extend time “either before or after the time expires”). Consequently the prohibition in r 31.28(3) will not apply where a party obtains an extension of the time for service and has served the expert report within the time permitted by that order. Neither will the r 31.28(4) requirement for “exceptional circumstances” apply to an application for an order extending the time for service: Tim Barr Pty Ltd v Naurui Gold Coast Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 506; BC200803779 at [17] .

level.toc-caption: [31.28.20] Exceptional circumstances

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 14, ss 56–58, s 62.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.28(3).
must be assessed against the particular statutory criterion and with a proper understanding of its rationale: R v Buckland [2000] 1 All ER 907 at 912–913; [2000] 1 WLR 1262 at 1268 .

must be more than circumstances that are regularly, routinely or normally encountered, although they need not be unique, or very rare: R v Kelly (Attorney-General's Reference No 53 of 1998) [2000] 1 QB 198 at 208; [1999] 2 All ER 13; [1999] 2 WLR 1100 .

may contribute to characterisation as “exceptional” because of the relative infrequency of their occurrence, and also by reference to their qualitative significance: R v Buckland, above at WLR 1268; All ER 912–913.

may derive their “exceptional” character from either a single exceptional matter or a combination of other factors which, taken individually may be either exceptional or ordinary: Ho v Professional Services Review Committee No 295 [2007] FCA 388; BC200701900 at [26].

The generality of the expression, understood in the light of the mandatory directions contained in CPA ss 56–58 , the directions power in CPA s 62 and the general discretion, conferred by CPA s 14 (to dispense with the requirements of the rules) suggests that, despite the difficulties of precise definition, the fundamental consideration in the exercise of the discretion to grant leave is the just determination of the proceedings: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2005] NSWSC 706; BC200505178 at [56]–[58] (ASIC v Rich). Consequently, principled exercise of the discretion will require consideration of the timing of any disclosure of the report, the reason for the late service, the apparent materiality of the evidence, the time available for hearing, the ability of the opposing party to meet the report and the availability of the expert for cross-examination. The mere fact that the opposing party is aware of the contents of the report is not necessarily sufficient to justify leave being granted to excuse non-compliance with the rule: Carey v Gruzman (NSWCA, Samuels, Priestley, Meagher JJA, 490/1988, 10 April 1991, unreported, BC9102125) at 10. On the other hand exceptional circumstances, sufficient to justify leave, may exist where the opposing party is not only aware of the contents of the report but has had ample notice of its likely tender (for example as a result of prior cross-examination) and the tender would not give rise to significant prejudice: New South Wales v Tyszyk [2008] NSWCA 107; BC200803881 at [188]–[208] esp [207]: see also [31.28.25] and [31.28.30] . The circumstance that the defendant puts to the plaintiff witnesses in cross-examination a scenario not previously raised in the evidence is a sufficiently exceptional circumstance to justify leave to adduce oral expert evidence: UCPR r 31.28(3) ; Quintano v BW Rose Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 956; BC200808437 at [5] .

level.toc-caption: [31.28.25] Exceptional circumstances: late service — availability of ameliorating conditions

heading.title: Exceptional circumstances: late service — availability of ameliorating conditions

p.text: Where the report is served very late there may be procedural means both of achieving the practical result intended by the present rule, and complying with the “overriding purpose” of the CPA and Rules. These procedural means may include deferring receipt of the evidence, deferring cross-examination, granting leave to further cross examine, (including by recalling the witness): Admont Holdings Pty Ltd v Lowe (1990) NSW ConvR ¶55-504; BC8901580 at 36. Obviously the possibility of framing directions to minimise the consequences of a failure to comply with the rule does not itself constitute “exceptional circumstances” but it is an important consideration, and may be determinative in cases where the tardily proffered evidence is critical to a fair and just determination of the real issues contested in the proceedings. Many cases have recognised the importance of avoiding the injustice that may arise where a party is prevented, by procedural restrictions or sanctions, from presenting a material part of the case they have to make in the proceedings: Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; BC9700005 ; Cameron v Baker (NSWCA, Samuels JA, 316/1989, 6 August 1980, unreported, BC8000055); Admont Holdings Pty Ltd v Lowe (NSWCA, Kirby P, 128/1988, 17 October 1989, unreported, BC8901580) at 38; Harding v Bourke (2000) 48 NSWLR 598 at 603; [2000] NSWCA 60; BC200001287 (the rules should not operate so as to frustrate or otherwise limit the requirements of doing justice between the parties); Western Sydney Area Health Service v Gibson [2001] NSWIRComm 290; (2001) 109 IR 359 at 367 ; Hyde v Energy Australia (1999) 92 IR 409 ; Jermen v Shell Co of Australia Ltd [2003] NSWSC 1106; BC200307299 .

level.toc-caption: [31.28.30] Exceptional circumstances: updating // supplementary report — prejudice

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.28(4).

heading.title: Exceptional circumstances: updating // supplementary report — prejudice

p.text: Different considerations may arise, and may be determinative, where the application for leave arises at a very late stage and relates to matters that have occurred in the course of the hearing. If the additional material is reasonably capable of being regarded as supplementary, either no leave is required under r 31.28(4) or the closeness of the relationship between the original and the further evidence may provide the “exceptional circumstances” required. On the other hand, the application may properly be rejected if it would introduce a substantial new area of factual enquiry (Admar Computers Pty Ltd v Ezy Systems Pty Ltd (FCA, Goldberg J, VG90 of 1995, 3 September 1997, unreported) — refusal to allow additional evidence in relation to expert’s assumption) or justify a substantial adjournment in favour of the opposing party: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2005] NSWSC 706; BC200505178 at [71]–[90] (additional expert accountant’s report tendered on 93rd hearing day after rejection of substantial parts of earlier report — leave refused); Stolfa v Owners Strata Plan 4366 (No 2) [2008] NSWSC 531; BC200804137 at [5]–[10] (further report in existence when joint expert appointed — insufficiently detailed — leave refused).

level.toc-caption: [31.28.35] Personal injury proceedings — single expert order

heading.title: Personal injury proceedings — single expert order

p.text: In personal injury proceedings the Supreme Court may order that relevant expert evidence be provided by a single expert agreed upon by the parties: see Practice Note SC Gen 10 and Practice Note SC CL 5 at [40]–[43].

level.toc-caption: [31.28.40] Privilege and improper use — served reports

heading.title: Privilege and improper use — served reports

p.text: An expert’s report obtained for the dominant purpose of the proceedings is subject to client legal privilege, even if it results from an examination of the opposing party or their property: Causton v Mann Egerton (Johnsons) Ltd [1974] 1 All ER 453; [1974] 1 WLR 162 : see also [21.5.35] . Any direction, rule or Practice Note requiring prior service operates conditionally and depends on the party’s intention to use the report in the proceedings. It does not itself abrogate the privilege that would otherwise apply: Comfort Hotels Ltd v Wembley Stadium Ltd [1988] 3 All ER 53; [1988] 1 WLR 872 . Furthermore actual service of reports in compliance with any direction or rule does not waive privilege: Dubbo City Council v Barrett [2003] NSWCA 267; BC200305990 (report privileged from production to co-defendant); New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 258; BC200701984 at [42] and [43] . Neither does the expert’s obligation to comply with the expert witness code: Roach v Page (No 17) [2003] NSWSC 973; BC200306353 .

Similarly, and unless the statement has actually been put into evidence, it is an abuse of process to use a served expert witness statement for any purpose other than the conduct of the proceedings in which it was served: Doubikin Holdings Pty Ltd v Grail Pty Ltd (1991) 5 WAR 563 at 585; [1992] ANZ ConvR 544 . See also Prudential Assurance Co Ltd v Fountain Page Ltd [1991] 3 All ER 878; [1991] 1 WLR 756 (reports served before settlement of proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [31.28.42] Privilege — expert reports, drafts, instructions and working papers

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.42] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 119(b).

heading.title: Privilege — expert reports, drafts, instructions and working papers

p.text: There are conflicting authorities as to whether common law legal professional privilege attaches to an expert witness’s documents that have not actually been communicated to the instructing client or their lawyer (eg the expert’s drafts and working papers). Some cases have held that uncommunicated documents could not attract privilege: Interchase Corp Ltd (in liq) v Grosvenor Hill (Qld) Pty Ltd (No 1) [1999] 1 Qd R 141 at 150–1, 153, 162 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Southcorp Ltd (2003) 46 ACSR 438; [2003] FCA 804; BC200304254 at [21] ; Temwell Pty Ltd v DKGR Holdings Pty Ltd [2003] FCA 948; BC200305132 ; Gate Gourmet Australia Pty Ltd v Gate Gourmet Holding AG [2004] NSWSC 768; BC200405612 ; Ryder v Frohlich [2005] NSWSC 1342; BC200511137 at [11] and [12] . Other cases have held that the dominant purpose for the creation of the drafts and working papers is the same as the purpose of the ultimate report and that they attract the privilege: Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (rec and mgrs apptd) (in liq) (2006) 203 FLR 1; 59 ACSR 87; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 at [16]–[20]; Linter Group Ltd v Price Waterhouse [1999] VSC 245; BC9903967 at [16] ; Filipowski v Island Maritime Ltd [2002] NSWLEC 177; BC200206331 at [22] .

Irrespective of any uncertainty in the common law position, s 119(b) of the Evidence Act 1995 expressly applies to the contents of confidential documents prepared for the dominant purpose of legal proceedings irrespective of whether or not they have been communicated: Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (rec and mgrs apptd) (in liq) (2006) 203 FLR 1; 59 ACSR 87; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 at [16]–[17]; Natuna Pty Ltd v Cook [2006] NSWSC 1367; BC200611213 at [8], [15] ; New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 258; BC200701984 at [18] and [34]ff . This criterion permits a factual inquiry about the dominant purpose for which particular documents have been created — and it is conceivable that the question may be answered differently according to whether the document is a draft or a final version intended for communication. If particular documents have been communicated to the instructing party’s lawyers that fact will ordinarily provide a proper basis for concluding that they were prepared for the required dominant purpose: New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 258; BC200701984 at [22] and [37] ; Brookfield v Yevad Products Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1180; BC200606822 at [15] .

Where an expert’s report has been deployed so as to waive privilege (for example by its voluntary disclosure or actual use in proceedings — but not mere service in compliance with a direction or order: see [31.28.40] ) the waiver impliedly extends to all communications between the party’s solicitor and the expert (including letters of instruction and other material) relied on by the expert for the purpose of their report: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Southcorp Ltd (2003) 46 ACSR 438; [2003] FCA 804; BC200304254 at [21] . The scope of any such waiver depends on satisfaction that the contents of the documents have apparently influenced the actual content of the report: Bourns Inc v Raychem Corp [1999] 3 All ER 154 (there must be at least reference to the document); Dingwall v Commonwealth (1992) 39 FCR 521 ; Tirango Nominees Pty Ltd v Dairy Vale Foods Ltd (No 2) (1998) 83 FCR 397; (1998) 156 ALR 364 at 367; BC9802845 . This implied disclosure will rarely extend to waive privilege that would otherwise apply to drafts of the expert’s opinion or communications with the instructing party’s lawyers about such drafts: New Cap Reinsurance Corporation Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd [2007] NSWSC 258; BC200701984 at [52]–[53] ; Nilsen Industrial Electronics Pty Ltd v National Semiconductor Corp (1994) 48 FCR 337 at 340; BC9406031 ; Argyle Brewery Pty Ltd (t/as Craig Brewery Bar & Grill) v Darling Harbourside (Sydney) Pty Ltd (1994) 48 FCR 1; 120 ALR 537. The essential reason for this conclusion is that the preparation of the report can reasonably be expected to involve a process of accumulating knowledge and analysis and that mere process of incremental awareness, analysis and possible revision will not ordinarily or necessarily provide a sufficient basis to justify a conclusion either that the draft reports are not privileged or that use of the final report impliedly waives that privilege: Linter Group Ltd v Price Waterhouse [1999] VSC 245; BC9903967 at [16] (draft report privileged from production — expert should be permitted/encouraged to change their mind if warranted); Filipowski v Island Maritime Ltd [2002] NSWLEC 177; BC200206331 (criminal proceedings, draft report privileged from production — should not be discouraged from changing mind or reformulating opinion after further reading or examination); Natuna Pty Ltd v Cook [2006] NSWSC 1367; BC200611213 (draft expert witness statements privileged under s 119(b) of the Evidence Act). However if an expert uses a draft for the purpose of refreshing their recollection in giving evidence, that will result in the loss of any privilege that would otherwise apply: MGICA (1992) Ltd v Kenny & Good Pty Ltd (No 2) (1996) 61 FCR 236; (1996) 135 ALR 743; BC9600195 .

level.toc-caption: [31.28.45] Refresher reports

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.18, r 31.28(4)(b), UCPR r 31.34.

An “updating” or “refresher” report, is excepted from the requirement for leave: r 31.28(4)(b) . Issues may arise as to what is truly updating. Such issues are resolved on a proper consideration of the inter alia the report and the issues in the proceedings: Tim Barr Pty Ltd v Naurui Gold Coast Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 506; BC200803779 at [17] (original “report” was evidence of contemporary events, not an “expert’s report” within the meaning of r 31.18 , therefore subsequent document did not “merely update” it). If a subsequent report materially alters opinions expressed in an earlier report it must be disclosed under UCPR r 31.34 .

level.toc-caption: [31.28.50] Reports tendered by consent

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.28.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56(3).

Leave is not required if the opposing party consents to the admission. And where a report is served late an astute forensic decision, made in conformity with a party’s obligations under ss 56(3) of the CPA, needs to be made by the opposing party as to whether to object to the tender of the report: Admont Holdings Pty Ltd v Lowe (1990) NSW ConvR ¶55-504; BC8901580 at 36 (an appeal against admission of a report was rejected in the absence of objection, or any application to delay cross-examination or adjourn the proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [31.28.55] Subpoena documents produced after the time for service

heading.title: Subpoena documents produced after the time for service

p.text: This rule applies to reports that are either in the possession of a party 28 days before the trial or where a party intends to use a particular expert’s report in evidence in the proceedings. The rule does not apply to reliance on an expert report of which the party was unaware at the relevant time — such as where the report is produced under subpoena at the trial: Dawson v Hall (NSWCA, Clarke, Meagher and Handley JJA, 40326/1992, 29 July 1994, unreported, BC9402852); Stedul v GIO (NSW) (NSWCA, Handley and Powell JJA, 40672/1993, 2 May 1995, unreported, BC9504542). However, independent issues of procedural fairness may arise where subpoenaed reports are sought to be relied upon.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.29] r 31.29 Admissibility of expert’s report (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13B)

leg:heading.title: Admissibility of expert’s report (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13B)

p.text: If an expert’s report is served in accordance with rule 31.28 or in accordance with an order of the court, the report is admissible:
as evidence of the expert’s opinion, and
if the expert’s direct oral evidence of a fact on which the opinion was based would be admissible, as evidence of that fact,
without further evidence, oral or otherwise.
Unless the court otherwise orders, a party may require the attendance for cross-examination of the expert by whom the report was prepared by notice served on the party by whom the report was served.
Unless the court otherwise orders, such a requirement may not be made later than:
in the case of proceedings for which the court has fixed a date for trial, 35 days before the date so fixed, or
in any other case, 7 days before the date on which the court fixes a date for trial.
The parties may not by consent abridge the time fixed by or under subrule (3).

If the expert’s attendance for cross-examination is required under subrule (2), the report may not be tendered under section 63 , 64 or 69 of the Evidence Act 1995 or otherwise used unless the expert attends or is dead or the court grants leave to use it.
The party using the report may re-examine the expert if the expert attends for cross-examination pursuant to a requirement under subrule (2).
This rule does not apply to proceedings in the District Court or the Local Court or to proceedings on a trial with a jury.
[subr (7) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]

level.toc-caption: [31.29.5] Desirability of oral evidence and requirement for cross-examination

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.29.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 31.28, 31.29.

heading.title: Desirability of oral evidence and requirement for cross-examination

p.text: The combined effect of rr 31.28 and 31.29 is that:
the substance of an expert’s evidence in chief must be contained in a written report;
the report must be served as required;
the report is admissible as evidence in chief irrespective of whether the expert gives oral evidence, but
the expert must attend for cross-examination if required.

The rules necessarily contemplate the possible absence of any oral expert evidence. But it is usually highly desirable that contested issues, to which any expert evidence is relevant, are the subject of oral evidence at the hearing. Those issues are likely to be more effectively addressed at the hearing of the proceedings by a combination of oral and written evidence than by the parties merely participating in the consensual tender of conflicting medical reports: Zaide v NSW Ministerial Insurance Corp (NSWCA, 26 March 1993, unreported); Austin v Director General of Education (1994) 10 NSWCCR 373; BC9402908 (Austin) per Powell JA; Government Insurance Office of NSW v Andrew (NSWCA, 40360 of 1991, 13 August 1992, unreported, BC9201678)(Andrew) per Samuels JA. Where conflicting medical reports are merely tendered, the absence of cross-examination may obscure the real issues in contest and result in a miscarriage of justice that requires a new trial: Laxy v IBM Australia Pty Ltd (1992) 35 FCR 79 at 86–7 . See also Wiechmann v Lovering (1992) 59 SASR 203 at 204, 208 and 212; 29 ALD 243 ; Austin per Powell JA; Andrew per Samuels JA.

level.toc-caption: [31.29.10] Expert opinion — admissibility

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.29.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 31.27, 31.34.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 135, s 79.

Compliance with the obligations imposed by UCPR rr 31.27 and 31.34 is a necessary, but not sufficient, precondition to the admissibility of the expert’s report. The report will only be admissible to the extent that:
the expert has the “specialised knowledge” required by s 79 of the Evidence Act 1995; and
the opinion contained in the report is “wholly or substantially based on that knowledge”.

These two requirements are separate and cumulative. Moreover, the expert report must adequately set out the factual matters (whether of observation, instruction or assumption) upon which the opinion has been based. It must also sufficiently demonstrate that those matters form a proper foundation for the opinion. The expert report must also show that the opinion is in fact relevantly based upon the application of the professed expertise to those factual matters: Makita (Australia) Pty Ltd v Sprowles (2001) 52 NSWLR 705; 25 NSWCCR 218; [2001] NSWCA 305; BC200105538 at [85] ; HG v R (1999) 197 CLR 414; 160 ALR 554; [1999] HCA 2; BC9900188 at [39] ; Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2001] NSWSC 123; BC200101607 at [83] ; Ocean Marine Mutual Insurance Association (Europe) OV v Jetopay Pty Ltd (2000) 120 FCR 146; [2000] FCA 1463; BC200007242 at [21], [23] . Where the report is based, either expressly or implicitly, on particular factual assumptions the accuracy of those assumptions is not a condition precedent to the admissibility of the report. Nor is the report inadmissible, nor necessarily liable to be excluded (under s 135 of the Evidence Act) as misleading or unfairly prejudicial, merely because the expert in fact had access to information other than that disclosed as the asserted basis of their evidence: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2005) 218 ALR 764; 54 ACSR 326; [2005] NSWCA 152; BC200503400 at [132]-[136], [163], [168] and [170] . However, specific statements of opinion within the report may be excluded where they are not sufficiently based on the matters disclosed: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2005] NSWSC 650; BC200504865 at [36]-[44] .

The “sufficiency” of the report in demonstrating its basis in “specialised knowledge” will often be determined by matters of judgment and impression, and involve questions of degree. Consequently it commonly and necessarily occurs that the question of admissibility is determined on the basis of the witness’ apparent expertise, the apparent relevance of the opinions contained in the report, and reasonable satisfaction that the opinions expressed are sufficiently based on the specialised knowledge professed by the witness: SydneyWide Distributors Pty Ltd v Red Bull Australia Pty Ltd (2002) 55 IPR 354; [2002] FCAFC 157; BC200202932 at [7], [9], [86], [87] ; Notaras v Hugh [2003] NSWSC 167; BC200301055 at [3], [8] (which addresses valuation evidence and the difficulty of complying with the requirement to state the factual matters forming the basis of the opinion); Adler v Australian Securities and Investments Commission (2003) 179 FLR 1; 46 ACSR 504 at 535; [2003] NSWCA 131; BC200303670 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Adler (2002) 20 ACLC 222; [2001] NSWSC 1103; BC200107461 (which deals with the admissibility of expert evidence about professional practice); Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Vines (2003) 48 ACSR 291; [2003] NSWSC 1095; BC200307191 (which deals with expert evidence about corporate governance and contains thorough discussion of the admissibility of different types of expert opinion).

The sufficiency of the witness’ disclosed reasoning to provide the required “reasonable satisfaction” will necessarily depend on the nature of the “specialised knowledge” concerned: see further Evidence Act 1995 s 79 .

Parties may waive objections to the admissibility of an expert report. A trial judge has no obligation to reject or ignore inadmissible evidence to which no objection has been taken. The weight to be given to evidence to which objection could properly have been made depends on its apparent logical and persuasive force: City Elevator Services Pty Ltd v Burrows [2004] NSWCA 26; BC200400594 .

level.toc-caption: [31.29.15] Determination of admissibility after voire dire examination

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.29.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 135, s 136.

heading.title: Determination of admissibility after voire dire examination

p.text: It may sometimes be desirable to conduct a voir dire examination in order to determine the admissibility of an expert's evidence. Where such an examination is proposed the party challenging the admissibility of the evidence should indicate the issues to be explored on the voire dire examination and satisfy the court that there is a significant issue of admissibility to be determined: R v Lars (aka Larsson) (1994) 73 A Crim R 91 at 119; BC9402668 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2004) 213 ALR 338; 51 ALSR 363; [2004] NSWSC 1062; BC200407579 (ASIC v Rich). In non jury trials the evidence given on the voire dire examination will be evidence in the proceedings unless a contrary order is made under s 135 or s 136 of the Evidence Act 1995: ASIC v Rich, above; Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [2002] NSWCA 419; BC200208153 at [201] ; Ex parte Whitelock; re McKenzie [1971] 2 NSWLR 534 at 539 ; Casley-Smith v FS Evans & Sons Pty Ltd (No 2) (1988) 49 SASR 332 at 333 .

level.toc-caption: [31.29.20] Privileged communications with an expert witness

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.29.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 7.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Sch K.

heading.title: Privileged communications with an expert witness

p.text: Confidential communications with the expert witness are still privileged, notwithstanding the expert witness’ obligation to comply with the Sch 7 (cf SCR Sch K ) code of conduct: Roach v Page (t/as Freehill Hollingdale and Page) (No 17) [2003] NSWSC 973; BC200306353 .

level.toc-caption: [31.29.25] Apprehended bias of expert

p.text: The apprehended partiality of an otherwise qualified expert witness does not itself render their evidence inadmissible: ASIC v Rich (2005) 190 FLR 242; 53 ACSR 110; [2005] NSWSC149; BC200501057 at [334] ; Flavel v South Australia (2007) SASR 505; [2007] SASC 50; BC200700675 at [95]–[102] (close commercial relationship with party — evidence admissible); Kirch Communications Pty Ltd v Gene Engineering Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 485; BC200203021 ; Fagenblat v Feingold Partners Pty Ltd [2001] VSC 454; BC200107393 (familial relationship — evidence admissible — not following Liverpool Roman Catholic Archdiocese Trustees Inc v Goldberg (No 2) [2001] 4 All ER 950; [2001] 1 WLR 2337 (close professional relationship)). The nature and extent of any relationship between an expert witness and a party may, nevertheless, be very relevant to a proper assessment of the weight that it is proper to accord to the expert’s opinion: Li v R [2003] NSWCCA 290; BC200306243 at [64]–[72] (expert voice similarity evidence — expert a serving police officer). For that reason the expert (and the party concerned) should disclose the relationship as part of the evidence: Whitehouse v Jordan [1981] 1 All ER 267; [1981] 1 WLR 246 at 256–57 per Lord Wilberforce; Fortson Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [2008] SASC 49; BC200801133 (valuer employed by bank at the time of a rehearing).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.30] r 31.30 Admissibility of expert’s report in District Court and Local Court (cf DCR Part 28, rule 9; LCR Part 23, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Admissibility of expert’s report in District Court and Local Court (cf DCR Part 28, rule 9; LCR Part 23, rule 2)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the District Court or the Local Court.
[subr (1) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
If an expert’s report is served in accordance with rule 31.28 or in accordance with an order of the court, the report is admissible:
as evidence of the expert’s opinion, and
if the expert’s direct oral evidence of a fact on which the opinion was based would be admissible, as evidence of that fact,
without further evidence, oral or otherwise.
Unless the court orders otherwise:
it is the responsibility of the party requiring the attendance for cross-examination of the expert by whom an expert’s report has been prepared to procure that attendance, and
the party requiring the expert’s attendance must notify the expert at least 28 days before the date on which attendance is required.

Except for the purpose of determining any liability for conduct money or witness expenses, an expert does not become the witness for the party requiring his or her attendance merely because his or her attendance at court has been procured by that party.
A party who requires the attendance of a person as referred to in subrule (2):
must inform all other parties to the proceedings that the party has done so at least 28 days before the date fixed for hearing, and

must pay to the person whose attendance is required (whether before or after the attendance) an amount sufficient to meet the person’s reasonable expenses (including any standby fees) in complying with the requirement.

If the attendance of an expert is required under subrule (2), the report may not be tendered under section 63 , 64 or 69 of the Evidence Act 1995 or otherwise used unless the expert attends or is dead or the court grants leave to use it.
The party using an expert’s report may re-examine an expert who attends for cross-examination under a requirement under subrule (2).
This rule does not apply to proceedings on a trial with a jury.
[r 31.30 am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[4], effective 6 July 2009]

level.toc-caption: [31.30.5] Procuring attendance for cross-examination

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.30.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.3.

This rule adopts the former District Court rule and places the onus on the opposing party to procure the attendance of an expert for cross-examination. A party who is out of time to procure the attendance of an expert required for cross-examination, should still find out whether the expert is actually able to attend the hearing — or is available to give evidence by telephone: see UCPR r 31.3 . If the expert is available, the party seeking to cross examine should take steps to secure the expert’s presence at court for cross-examination, or make arrangements to obtain an effective order under UCPR r 31.3. This may include arranging for travel and accommodation (to limit the prejudice that may flow from late service) and the issue of a subpoena. In a lengthy hearing the fact that the expert may not be required for cross-examination until well after the hearing has commenced may often alleviate any prejudice, particularly if a convenient time for the expert’s attendance can be nominated or even agreed.

level.toc-caption: [31.30.10] Discretion to otherwise order

p.text: Where an application is made for the court to require attendance of an expert for cross-examination, some explanation ought to be given for the failure to give notice and the relevance of the proposed cross-examination: Forbes Shire Council v Jones [1999] NSWCA 419; BC9907501 at [34] .

level.toc-caption: [31.30.15] Leave considerations

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.31] r 31.31 Fees for medical expert for compliance with subpoena (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13BA)

leg:heading.title: Fees for medical expert for compliance with subpoena (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13BA)

p.text: If a subpoena is served on a medical expert who is to give evidence of medical matters but is not called as a witness, the expert is, unless the court orders otherwise, entitled to be paid, in addition to any other amount payable to the expert, the amount specified in item 2 of Schedule 3 .
The amount payable under subrule (1) must be paid to the expert by the issuing party within 28 days after the date for the expert’s attendance.

A party that requires an expert’s attendance under rule 31.29(2) , but subsequently revokes it, must pay to the issuing party any amount paid by the issuing party under subrule (2), but otherwise such an amount is not recoverable by the issuing party from any other party unless the court so orders.
In this rule, issuing party means the party at whose request a subpoena is issued.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.32] r 31.32 Service of subpoena on medical expert (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13BB)

leg:heading.title: Service of subpoena on medical expert (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13BB)

p.text: Service of a subpoena on a medical expert may be effected, at any place at which the expert’s practice is carried on, by handing it over to a person who is apparently engaged in the practice (whether as an employee or otherwise) and is apparently of or above the age of 16 years.
If a person refuses to accept a subpoena when it is handed over, the subpoena may be served by putting it down in the person’s presence after he or she has been told of its nature.

If a subpoena requires a medical expert to attend court on a specified date for the purpose of giving evidence on medical matters, it must be served on the expert not later than 21 days before the date so specified unless the court orders otherwise.
The parties may not by consent abridge the time fixed by or under subrule (3).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.33] r 31.33 Subpoena requiring production of medical records (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13BC)

leg:heading.title: Subpoena requiring production of medical records (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13BC)

p.text: A subpoena for production may require a medical expert to produce medical records or copies of them.

A person is not required to comply with a subpoena for production referred to in subrule (1) unless the amount specified in item 3 of Schedule 3 is paid or tendered to the person at the time of service of the subpoena or a reasonable time before the date on which production is required.
Rule 33.6 (Compliance with subpoena) does not apply to a subpoena to which subrule (1) applies.
Rule 33.7 (Production otherwise than on attendance) applies to the photocopies in the same way as it applies to the records.

If, after service of a subpoena for production referred to in subrule (1), the party who requested the issue of the subpoena requires production of the original medical records without the option of producing copies of them, the party must request the issue of, and serve, another subpoena requiring production of the original medical records.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.34] r 31.34 Supplementary reports by expert witness (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13C; DCR Part 28, rule 9C; LCR Part 23, rule 1D)

leg:heading.title: Supplementary reports by expert witness (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13C; DCR Part 28, rule 9C; LCR Part 23, rule 1D)

p.text: If an expert witness provides a supplementary report to the party by whom he or she has been engaged, neither the engaging party nor any other party having the same interest as the engaging party may use:
the supplementary report, or
any earlier report affected by the supplementary report,
unless all of those reports have been served on all parties affected.

For the purposes of this rule, supplementary report, in relation to an earlier report provided by an expert witness, includes any report by the expert witness that indicates that he or she has changed his or her opinion on a material matter expressed in the earlier report.
This rule does not apply to a report prepared by a court-appointed expert.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.35] r 31.35 Opinion evidence by expert witnesses (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 34A, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Opinion evidence by expert witnesses (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 34A, rule 3 )

p.text: In any proceedings in which two or more parties call expert witnesses to give opinion evidence about the same issue or similar issues, or indicate to the court an intention to call expert witnesses for that purpose, the court may give any one or more of the following directions:
a direction that, at trial:
the expert witnesses give evidence after all factual evidence relevant to the issue or issues concerned, or such evidence as may be specified by the court, has been adduced, or
the expert witnesses give evidence at any stage of the trial, whether before or after the plaintiff has closed his or her case, or

each party intending to call one or more expert witnesses close that party’s case in relation to the issue or issues concerned, subject only to adducing evidence of the expert witnesses later in the trial,
a direction that, after all factual evidence relevant to the issue, or such evidence as may be specified by the court, has been adduced, each expert witness file an affidavit or statement indicating:
whether the expert witness adheres to any opinion earlier given, or
whether, in the light of any such evidence, the expert witness wishes to modify any opinion earlier given,
a direction that the expert witnesses:
be sworn one immediately after another (so as to be capable of making statements, and being examined and cross-examined, in accordance with paragraphs (d), (e), (f), (g) and (h)), and
when giving evidence, occupy a position in the courtroom (not necessarily the witness box) that is appropriate to the giving of evidence,
a direction that each expert witness give an oral exposition of his or her opinion, or opinions, on the issue or issues concerned,
a direction that each expert witness give his or her opinion about the opinion or opinions given by another expert witness,
a direction that each expert witness be cross-examined in a particular manner or sequence,
a direction that cross-examination or re-examination of the expert witnesses giving evidence in the circumstances referred to in paragraph (c) be conducted:
by completing the cross-examination or re-examination of one expert witness before starting the cross-examination or re-examination of another, or
by putting to each expert witness, in turn, each issue relevant to one matter or issue at a time, until the cross-examination or re-examination of all of the expert witnesses is complete,

a direction that any expert witness giving evidence in the circumstances referred to in paragraph (c) be permitted to ask questions of any other expert witness together with whom he or she is giving evidence as so referred to,
such other directions as to the giving of evidence in the circumstances referred to in paragraph (c) as the court thinks fit.

level.toc-caption: [31.35.5] Time and manner of expert evidence — concurrent evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.35.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.35, r 31.35(d)–(h).

heading.title: Time and manner of expert evidence — concurrent evidence

p.text: This rule, modelled on a provision in the rules of the Federal Court of Australia, provides a number of specific powers intended to facilitate the effective use of expert evidence in proceedings. The most significant aspect of these powers is that of having expert witnesses sworn “one immediately after another”, requiring the expert witnesses to give their evidence sequentially and inviting them to comment on, or ask questions about, the evidence given by other expert witnesses.

The procedure is intended to facilitate a more investigative, less adversarial and a more direct approach to resolving differences between conflicting expert opinions. These benefits are conceived to flow from the procedures involved in establishing an agenda for the consideration of the expert evidence, highlighting where the experts differ about factual assumptions rather than matters of specialised knowledge, and from the contemporaneous exchange of views by the respective expert witnesses. Another perceived advantage of the concurrent evidence procedure is that of enhancing the overall quality of expert evidence, by providing the most effective environment for testing the real basis for the opinions expressed and the real relevance and materiality of the witnesses’ professed specialised knowledge.

Concurrent evidence has been widely used in the Federal Court of Australia, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Land and Environment Court of NSW. There is an explanation of the history and techniques of concurrent evidence procedures see Rares J “Using the ‘Hot tub’ — How concurrent expert evidence aids understanding issues” paper presented to the NSW Bar Association Continuing Professional Development Seminar, 23 August 2010, published on the Federal Court website at http://www.fedcourt.gov.au/aboutct/judges_papers/speeches_raresj12.html .

The use of concurrent procedures in the Land and Environment Court, endorsing the effectiveness of the procedure is outlined in McClellan CJ “Expert Witnesses — The experience of the Land and Environment Court of New South Wales” XIX Biennial Lawasia Conference 2005 , Gold Coast 20–24 March 2005, at pp 17–20. The experience and practices developed in the Supreme Court of NSW are discussed in Garling J “Concurrent Expert Evidence: Reflections and Development” (2011) 49 Law Society Journal 10.

The particular directions authorised in UCPR r 31.35(d)–(h) suggest considerable flexibility in the actual process of giving evidence concurrently. That flexibility is reflected in variability in the practices adopted by different courts and judges. Some judges prefer to allow the parties to conduct examination and cross-examination. Other judges adopt a practice, likely informed by any joint expert report, of questioning the expert witnesses before any examination or cross-examination by the parties. In the former case the expectation is that the parties will question the witnesses in a more constructive manner than might occur in traditional cross-examination. In the latter case there is a perception that expert witnesses are potentially less likely to respond to the decision maker’s questioning by adhering to partisan or marginal views: see “Expert Witnesses” NSW Law Reform Commission Report 109 (2005) ¶6.56. Whichever practice is adopted, it is common for the parties to be limited as to the topics they are able to pursue in cross-examination, the sequence in which those topics are addressed and the time available for the cross-examination. See X v Sydney Children’s Hospitals Specialty Network (No 7) [2011] NSWSC 1360; BC201108918 .

level.toc-caption: [31.35.10] Concurrent evidence in personal injury proceedings

heading.title: Concurrent evidence in personal injury proceedings

p.text: Personal injury proceedings in the Supreme Court are subject to Practice Note SC CL 5 . Paragraphs 36 to 40 of the Practice Note apply to expert evidence in the proceedings and stipulate that all expert evidence is to be given concurrently, unless there a single expert witness has been appointed or a contrary direction is made. The parties are required to prepare a schedule of issues for the expert evidence, and the appropriateness of their consideration by a single expert, or by concurrent expert evidence. The parties are to provide concurrent experts with a list of questions. The concurrent experts are required to meet and provide a report on the matters on which they agree and disagree. These procedures require the representatives of the parties, and the expert witnesses, to prepare for the concurrent evidence session by familiarising themselves with the process, and its effective application in the particular proceedings: Willett v United Concrete Pty Ltd (2009) 190 IR 28; [2009] NSWSC 957; BC200908675 at [54]–[56].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.36] r 31.36 Service of experts’ reports in professional negligence claims (cf SCR Part 14C, rules 1 and 6; DCR Part 28, rule 9B)

leg:heading.title: Service of experts’ reports in professional negligence claims (cf SCR Part 14C, rules 1 and 6; DCR Part 28, rule 9B)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a person commencing a professional negligence claim (other than a claim against a legal practitioner) must file and serve, with the statement of claim commencing the professional negligence claim, an expert’s report that includes an opinion supporting:
the breach of duty of care, or contractual obligation, alleged against each person sued for professional negligence, and
the general nature and extent of damage alleged (including death, injury or other loss or harm and prognosis, as the case may require), and
the causal relationship alleged between such breach of duty or obligation and the damage alleged.
In the case of a professional negligence claim against a legal practitioner, the court may order the plaintiff to file and serve an expert’s report or experts’ reports supporting the claim.

If a party fails to comply with subrule (1) or (2), the court may by order made on the application of a party or of its own motion dismiss the whole or any part of the proceedings, as may be appropriate.
Without limiting subrule (1) or (2), the court may, on the application of any of the parties, give directions as to the expert evidence to be adduced at trial.
[subr (4) subst Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 6 July 2007]
Directions under subrule (4) may be sought at any directions hearing or case management conference or by notice of motion.
[subr (5) insrt Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 6 July 2007]
Unless the court otherwise orders, no party may adduce any expert evidence at trial unless the evidence:
has been filed and served under subrule (1) or (2), or
has been served pursuant to directions given under subrule (4).
[subr (6) insrt Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 6 July 2007]

level.toc-caption: [31.36.5] Professional negligence claims

p.text: Professional negligence claims are defined in the Dictionary to include claims against medical and related health practitioners and service providers and also claims against legal practitioners.
